The World Health Organization (WHO) has been working with ministries of health and other stakeholders of Pacific island countries to build climate resilient health systems. Although a disease-specific approach is useful initially, in the long run a comprehensive intersectoral programme is required. As recommended by WHO,
6 this programme should address (i) health governance and policies tackling climate risks; (ii) health information, integrated surveillance and climate early warning systems; and (iii) preventive and curative services (water and sanitation, pest and vector control, food safety, disaster risk management for health, safe and environmentally sustainable health facilities, vaccination and child health services).
